races.name: Men's Elite Road Race | 2026 Australian Road National Championships
races.description: 177km circuit race through Perth's CBD and Kings Park featuring 13 laps of a 13.6km circuit. The course is defined by the steep pinch of Malcolm Street (aka 'Pedal Mafia Mountain') that peaks just 400 metres before the finish line, making it a punchy finale where every lap builds suspense.

primary.notes: Full 3h 36m race replay - FREE in Australia
Full race replay (Elite Men's & Women's Road Races)
Full race replay (Elite Men's & Women's Road Races)
Full race replay (Elite Men's & Women's Road Races)

youtubeChannels.notes: Combined Elite Road Races highlights (8 min) - CONTAINS SPOILERS

broadcast.notes: SBS On Demand is geo-restricted to Australia. FloBikes provides worldwide coverage with subscription.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The 2026 Australian Road National Championships moved to Perth, Western Australia for a three-year stint after two decades at Buninyong in Victoria. The 177km elite men's race covers 13 laps of a 13.6km circuit through Perth's CBD and the leafy Kings Park. Unlike Buninyong's defining single climb, Perth's course spreads the climbing over an uphill drag in the first half and punchy pinches in the final stages. The defining feature is Malcolm Street - dubbed 'Pedal Mafia Mountain' - a steep pinch that peaks just 400 metres before the finish line, making for an explosive finale on every lap.

keySectors.name: Malcolm Street (Pedal Mafia Mountain)
keySectors.description: The course's defining feature - a steep pinch climb peaking 400m before the finish line. Repeated 13 times, it becomes more decisive as the race progresses.

keyClimbs.name: Kings Park ascent
keyClimbs.notes: Uphill drag through leafy Kings Park - first half of each lap

keyClimbs.name: Malcolm Street
keyClimbs.notes: The 'Pedal Mafia Mountain' - explosive pinch 400m from finish

gcContenders: Jay Vine (UAE Team Emirates - XRG) - TT specialist also capable on punchy terrain
Luke Plapp - Reigning Australian ITT champion
Jai Hindley (Red Bull - BORA - hansgrohe) - Perth local and Tour de France stage winner
sprinters: Sam Welsford (Red Bull - BORA - hansgrohe) - Perth local with explosive sprint, won 2025 edition
puncheurs: Team Jayco AlUla riders - Australia's WorldTour team enters with multiple options

narratives: Perth locals Jai Hindley and Sam Welsford racing for the green-and-gold jersey in their hometown - extra motivation for the BORA duo
Jay Vine seeking to add the road title to his TT crown - UAE's climbing specialist showing form early in the season
Team Jayco AlUla as Australia's only WorldTour team entering with tactical options
New Perth course creates unpredictability - riders haven't fully decoded the Malcolm Street dynamic yet
The green-and-gold jersey is the most coveted prize in Australian cycling - WorldTour stars interrupt European preparations to compete
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Australian Road National Championships have been held annually since 1901, making it one of the oldest national championships in world cycling. The event spent two decades on a fixed course near Ballarat, Victoria, with its race-shaping Buninyong climb becoming iconic. The 2025 move to Perth marked a new era, with a circuit format that rewards different rider characteristics than the climbing-heavy Buninyong course.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Watch for the Malcolm Street pinch on each lap - as fatigue builds through 13 laps, this explosive climb becomes increasingly selective. The Perth course proved more decisive than it appears on paper in 2025, with few opportunities to rest. The flat-ish final kilometers after Malcolm Street make it possible for a small group to stay away, but also allows sprinters to hang on if they survive the climb. Expect attacking racing from the Perth locals eager to perform in front of home fans.

races.name: Women's Elite Road Race | 2026 Australian Road National Championships
races.description: 109km circuit race through Perth's CBD and Kings Park featuring 8 laps of a 13.6km circuit. The course is defined by the steep pinch of Malcolm Street (aka 'Pedal Mafia Mountain') that peaks just 400 metres before the finish line.

primary.notes: Full 3h 4m race replay - FREE in Australia (Episode 3)
Combined broadcast with Elite Men's race
Combined broadcast with Elite Men's race
Combined broadcast with Elite Men's race

youtubeChannels.notes: Combined Elite Road Races highlights (8 min) - CONTAINS SPOILERS

broadcast.notes: SBS has dedicated women's race replay. FloBikes stream combines both Elite Men's and Women's races.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The 2026 Australian Road National Championships moved to Perth, Western Australia for a three-year stint. The 109km elite women's race covers 8 laps of a 13.6km circuit through Perth's CBD and the leafy Kings Park. The defining feature is Malcolm Street - dubbed 'Pedal Mafia Mountain' - a steep pinch that peaks just 400 metres before the finish line, making for an explosive finale on every lap.

keySectors.name: Malcolm Street (Pedal Mafia Mountain)
keySectors.description: The course's defining feature - a steep pinch climb peaking 400m before the finish line. Repeated 8 times, it becomes more decisive as the race progresses.

keyClimbs.name: Kings Park ascent
keyClimbs.notes: Uphill drag through leafy Kings Park - first half of each lap

keyClimbs.name: Malcolm Street
keyClimbs.notes: The 'Pedal Mafia Mountain' - explosive pinch 400m from finish

allRounders: Grace Brown - Olympic time trial champion returning to domestic racing
Ruby Roseman-Gannon (Liv-AlUla-Jayco) - 2025 Australian road race champion
Amanda Spratt (Lidl-Trek) - veteran climber and multiple national champion
sprinters: Alexandra Manly (AG Insurance-Soudal) - fast finish if it comes to a group sprint
puncheurs: Liv-AlUla-Jayco riders - Australia's women's WorldTour team with tactical options

narratives: Ruby Roseman-Gannon defending her 2025 road race title on the new Perth course
Grace Brown returning as Olympic champion - can she add the national title?
Liv-AlUla-Jayco as Australia's women's WorldTour team with multiple cards to play
New Perth circuit favors punchy riders who can handle repeated attacks on Malcolm Street
The green-and-gold jersey is the most coveted prize in Australian women's cycling
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Australian Women's Road National Championships have grown in prestige as the women's peloton has expanded. Recent champions include some of the best riders in world cycling, with the green-and-gold jersey a prized possession that riders race for before heading to Europe.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Watch for the Malcolm Street pinch on each lap - as fatigue builds through 8 laps, this explosive climb becomes increasingly selective. The shorter women's race (109km vs 177km for men) means the pace is high from the start. Expect attacking racing from Liv-AlUla-Jayco looking to control for their protected riders.

races.name: Women's Tour Down Under 2026
races.description: Three-stage women's race through South Australia's wine country, featuring the iconic Corkscrew Road climb

primary.notes: Full live coverage and replays - Canada only
Free highlights on TNT Sports YouTube

broadcast.notes: FloBikes has full coverage (Canada only). YouTube highlights available globally.

stages.name: Stage 1
stages.description: Opening stage of the Women's Tour Down Under

stages.name: Stage 2: Corkscrew Road
stages.description: Queen stage featuring the iconic Corkscrew Road climb

stages.name: Stage 3: Campbelltown
stages.description: Final stage with circuit finish in Campbelltown

alternatives.notes: Extended stage highlights posted after each stage

primary.notes: FREE live coverage on 7plus streaming and Seven TV. Commentary team includes Grace Brown, Mark Beretta, Matthew Keenan, Phil Liggett, Robbie McEwen, and Gracie Elvin.

youtubeChannels.notes: Men's Race Preview - course analysis and favorites

broadcast.notes: Race runs Jan 20-25, 2026. FREE live coverage on 7plus (Australia only). YouTube highlights typically posted same day after each stage.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Tour Down Under opens the WorldTour season each January in South Australia. This 6-stage race (including prologue) features two decisive mountain stages in the Adelaide Hills - Stage 2 on the feared Corkscrew Road and Stage 4 featuring the iconic triple ascent of Willunga Hill. The format creates multiple GC opportunities: the prologue establishes early gaps, Corkscrew Road on Stage 2 provides the first major test, and Willunga Hill typically decides the ochre jersey on Stage 4. The final stage now features a circuit finish rather than a traditional sprint, adding drama to the finale.

keyClimbs.name: Willunga Hill
keyClimbs.notes: Triple ascent on queen stage - decisive for GC. 3km at 7.5% avg, final ascent to finish line.

keyClimbs.name: Corkscrew Road
keyClimbs.notes: Double ascent - early GC shaker. 2.5km at 9.7% avg, up to 16% max. First serious test of legs.

keyClimbs.name: Norton Summit
keyClimbs.notes: Opening climb on Stage 2, sets up Corkscrew attacks.

keyClimbs.name: Menglers Hill
keyClimbs.notes: Triple ascent in Barossa Valley, opener for punchy riders.

gcContenders: Jhonatan Narváez (UAE Team Emirates-XRG) - Defending champion
Jay Vine (UAE Team Emirates-XRG) - Strong climber for Willunga
Ben O'Connor (Jayco AlUla) - Local favorite, previous podium finisher
Matthew Brennan (Visma-Lease a Bike) - Rising GC talent
Adam Yates (UAE Team Emirates-XRG) - Grand Tour experience

narratives: Narváez defends: Can UAE's defending champion repeat on the toughest TDU course ever?
UAE Team Emirates-XRG brings overwhelming depth with Narváez, Vine, and Yates - team tactics will be fascinating
Ben O'Connor returns home seeking redemption after near-misses at previous editions
Matthew Brennan's breakthrough? The young Visma rider could announce himself on the WorldTour stage
Three Willunga ascents unprecedented - the queen stage will rewrite TDU history
New circuit finish at Stirling creates unpredictable finale - can GC leaders survive?
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Tour Down Under has been the traditional WorldTour season opener since 1999, held annually in the Adelaide region of South Australia. Willunga Hill became a TDU staple in 2008 and has since become one of the most iconic climbs in Australian cycling, consistently producing exciting racing and GC drama. Past champions include a who's who of Grand Tour winners and classics specialists.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The race is won and lost in the Adelaide Hills. Focus on Corkscrew Road (Stage 2) for early GC moves, then Willunga Hill (Stage 4) for the decisive battle. The prologue gaps can prove crucial - even 10-15 seconds provides valuable buffer for mountain stages. Watch for heat-related tactics and the new circuit finale format on Stage 5.
raceDetails.gcDynamics: Prologue creates initial gaps → Stage 2 Corkscrew provides first serious selection → Stage 3 transitional day with breakaway potential → Stage 4 Willunga typically decides GC → Stage 5 circuit finale can produce late attacks

stages.name: Prologue: Adelaide → Adelaide (ITT)
stages.description: Short 3.6km individual time trial from the City of Adelaide Tour Village to Victoria Park. Flat run-out with a twisting conclusion - a sharp wake-up call for legs after the off-season.

stageDetails.courseSummary: A 3.6km twilight time trial through Adelaide's heart - only the second prologue in TDU history. Starting from the City of Adelaide Tour Village in the CBD, riders face a straight, flat run-out before a twisting technical conclusion in Victoria Park. Race Director Stuart O'Grady calls it 'a violent effort and stark wake-up call for riders' legs after months away from competition.'
stageDetails.watchNotes: The prologue shakes up race dynamics from day one - riders 10-20 seconds behind will need to attack later in the week. TT specialists and GC contenders will be fighting for every second. Watch for the technical corners in Victoria Park where time can be gained or lost.

stages.name: Stage 1: Tanunda → Tanunda
stages.description: Circuit through Barossa wine country with three ascents of Menglers Hill. Flat finish after a fast descent suits the sprinters, but breakaways could survive.

stageDetails.courseSummary: The first road stage circles through the stunning Barossa wine country, starting and finishing in Tanunda. Three ascents of Menglers Hill provide the climbing challenge, but this year's direction makes the climb gentler than previous editions. A wickedly fast descent leads to a flat run-in of 13km to the finish.

keyClimbs.name: Menglers Hill
keyClimbs.notes: Climbed 3 times - gentler direction than 2025

stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprinters' teams will control the peloton on the flat finish, but breakaways have a chance if they survive the Menglers Hill circuits. Watch for white-knuckle moments on the fast descent before the final 13km. Last year Sam Welsford won the sprint here despite a late crash.

stages.name: Stage 2: Norwood → Uraidla
stages.description: The feared Corkscrew Road (9.7% avg) features twice - midway and 14km from the finish. Also includes Norton Summit and Mount Lofty climbs. A true GC shaker.

stageDetails.courseSummary: The queen stage of the Adelaide Hills - a true GC shaker with two ascents of the feared Corkscrew Road. Starting in Norwood, riders tempo through Norton Summit and tackle Mount Lofty before the first Corkscrew assault at mid-stage. The second Corkscrew comes with 14km to go, followed by an undulating approach to Uraidla. A downhill run-in offers one last chance for the peloton to catch escapees.

keyClimbs.name: Corkscrew Road (1st)
keyClimbs.notes: First of two ascents

keyClimbs.name: Corkscrew Road (2nd)
keyClimbs.notes: Final climb - decisive moment

stageDetails.watchNotes: The Corkscrew's 9.7% average gradient is brutal - expect attacks on both ascents. The undulating 14km after the final Corkscrew will test any solo riders' wills. GC contenders will show their cards here. This is where the race for the ochre jersey truly begins.

stages.name: Stage 3: Henley Beach → Nairne
stages.description: Starting at the beach but no holiday - Wickham Hill (3km at 7%, max 11%) comes early. Mount Barker climb at 115km is short but tough, possibly not enough to drop sprinters.

stageDetails.courseSummary: Starting at idyllic seaside suburb Henley Beach (hosting a stage start for the first time), this is no holiday - punchy climbs await. Wickham Hill comes early at 32km, followed by Chandlers Hill. Mount Barker Summit with less than 5km to the finish provides the final test. First-ever stage finish in the Mount Barker Council town of Nairne.

keyClimbs.name: Wickham Hill
keyClimbs.notes: 207m elevation gain - too early for GC attacks

keyClimbs.name: Mount Barker Summit
keyClimbs.notes: Short but tough - may not drop sprinters

stageDetails.watchNotes: This is the Adelaide Epic Ride route for public participants. Wickham Hill's 11% max gradient is punishing early on. The Mount Barker climb is short but could still cause damage on tired legs. Sprinters may survive if their teams control the pace - watch for a potential bunch sprint in Nairne.

stages.name: Stage 4: Brighton → Willunga Hill
stages.description: Queen stage with 2,500m+ climbing. Three ascents of iconic Willunga Hill including two in the final 26km. The longest and hardest day - a climber's paradise.

stageDetails.courseSummary: The longest and hardest day - the iconic queen stage with over 2,500m of climbing. Starting in Brighton, Chandlers Hill comes in the first 15km. Then three ascents of the legendary Willunga Hill: first topping out after 50km, then two more in the final 26km via McLaren Flat and McLaren Vale. A climber's paradise with a summit finish on Australia's most famous cycling climb.

keyClimbs.name: Chandlers Hill
keyClimbs.notes: Early warm-up for legs

keyClimbs.name: Willunga Hill (1st)
keyClimbs.notes: First ascent after 50km

keyClimbs.name: Willunga Hill (2nd)
keyClimbs.notes: Second ascent - attacks begin

keyClimbs.name: Willunga Hill (Final)
keyClimbs.notes: Summit finish - decisive for GC

stageDetails.watchNotes: Willunga Hill is TDU's most iconic climb - expect huge crowds lining the road. The triple ascent in 2026 is a new twist on the classic. GC contenders must attack here or lose the race. Race Director O'Grady: 'It's certainly going to be a day for the climbers and the winner will really have to earn it.'

stages.name: Stage 5: Stirling → Stirling
stages.description: Eight laps of a punchy 21km circuit with saw-blade profile. Four classified climbs plus Mount Barker Road finish (2km, 4% avg but 11% max). World championship-style finale where anything can happen.

stageDetails.courseSummary: A revolutionary finale for the Tour Down Under - the final day moves from a sprint-friendly city stage to an aggressive world championship-style circuit. Eight laps of a punchy 21km circuit around Stirling with a saw-blade profile. Four classified climbs per lap before the finishing ascent on Mount Barker Road. Race Director O'Grady calls it 'the best final stage we've ever had.'

keyClimbs.name: Mount Barker Road (per lap)
keyClimbs.notes: 78m elevation gain - deceptive average hides 11% pitches

stageDetails.watchNotes: This is a whole new ball game for TDU. O'Grady: 'Even if you're within a minute of the lead, if the racing is hard and smart enough, you have the potential to destroy the ochre jersey.' Eight laps means repeated attacks and no hiding. Watch for aggressive racing on the punchy climbs and the decisive 11% gradients of Mount Barker Road. Stirling offers a perfect viewing platform with great food, drink options and shade.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Women's One-Day Race is a fast 94.2km criterium-style event held in Tanunda, the heart of South Australia's Barossa Valley wine country. Racing takes place on a 8km circuit, with riders completing approximately 12 laps through the historic town streets. The flat to rolling terrain with six intermediate sprints favors fast finishers and sprinters who can handle the repetitive circuit racing.

sprinters: Ally Wollaston (FDJ United-SUEZ) - Dominant form in 2026 stage race
Marion Bunel (Visma-Lease a Bike) - Fast finishing ability
puncheurs: Noemi Rüegg (EF Education-Oatly) - Defending TDU champion
allRounders: Amanda Spratt (Lidl-Trek) - Former winner, final season

narratives: Ally Wollaston arrives as the rider to beat after dominating the Women's Tour Down Under stage race
Amanda Spratt's farewell tour - the Australian legend in her final professional season seeks home glory
World champion Magdeleine Vallieres makes her 2026 debut with EF Education-Oatly
Noemi Rüegg looks to add the One-Day Race to her 2025 TDU GC title
Circuit racing in Barossa wine country - tactical positioning and timing are everything
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Women's One-Day Race in Tanunda was added to the Santos Tour Down Under festival to give riders an additional competitive opportunity during the Australian summer racing block. The fast circuit racing provides a different test to the climbing-focused Women's Tour Down Under stages.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Watch for breakaway attempts on the early laps as teams test each other. The six intermediate sprints keep the race animated throughout. In the closing laps, expect positioning battles as sprinters' teams try to control the front for a bunch kick. The flat circuit rewards tactical racing and good pack positioning.

primary.notes: FREE live coverage on 7plus streaming and Seven TV

broadcast.notes: Part of the Santos Tour Down Under festival week. Held on January 21, 2026, immediately after the 3-stage Women's Tour Down Under.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Women's Surf Coast Classic is a challenging 118km race from Lorne to Torquay along Victoria's spectacular Great Ocean Road coastline. The race features rolling terrain with a significant 10km climb at the start that immediately puts pressure on the peloton. Coastal winds and exposed roads create unpredictable racing conditions, while the scenic route through surf coast communities provides a stunning backdrop.

keyClimbs.name: Opening Climb
keyClimbs.notes: 10km climb at race start, puts weaker riders on the back foot immediately

puncheurs: Riders who can handle the early climb and coastal winds
allRounders: Strong all-rounders who thrive in unpredictable conditions
sprinters: Fast finishers who can survive the early climb

narratives: Mid-week warm-up race before Saturday's WorldTour Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race
First ever women's edition of the Surf Coast Classic - a milestone for equality in Australian cycling
Teams use this as final preparation for the marquee weekend WorldTour event
Coastal winds and exposed roads can split the peloton unexpectedly
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Surf Coast Classic was established as part of the Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race festival week. The women's edition was added to provide parity with the men's race, giving riders an additional competitive opportunity on the Victoria coastline before the weekend's WorldTour action.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The early 10km climb immediately sets the tone - watch for aggressive racing from teams looking to shed pure sprinters. Coastal crosswinds on exposed sections can cause splits. Teams with WorldTour ambitions will use this as a tactical rehearsal for Saturday's bigger prize.

broadcast.notes: Part of the Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race festival week.

races.name: Surf Coast Classic Men
races.description: ProSeries race from Lorne to Torquay featuring rolling coastal terrain with early climbs - warm-up for Cadel Evans race

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Surf Coast Classic runs 157km from Lorne to Torquay, starting with a 10km climb towards Deans Marsh. From there riders head through Barwon Downs and Forrest before meandering through rural countryside to Modewarre, then back to the coast for the finish. Climbs concentrated in first half, with flatter second half typically resulting in a sprint finish.

keyClimbs.name: Deans Marsh Climb
keyClimbs.notes: First major climb out of Lorne

raceDetails.watchNotes: Crosswinds can split the race on exposed coastal sections. Despite rolling terrain in first half, the race typically comes together for a sprint finish in Torquay. Well-organized leadout trains usually prevail.

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race (Women)
races.description: First one-day race of the Women's WorldTour - 141km through Victoria's Bellarine Peninsula with the decisive Challambra Crescent climb

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Mapei Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race – Women is the first one-day race of the Women's WorldTour season. The 141km course winds through the Bellarine Peninsula and Surf Coast, featuring more than 1,500 metres of elevation gain and stunning coastal scenery. The decisive Challambra Crescent climb, topping out 9km from the finish, is the key selection point before the fast finish on the Geelong waterfront.

keyClimbs.name: Challambra Crescent
keyClimbs.notes: The decisive climb - punchy gradient tests sprinters and often creates the winning selection

puncheurs: Strong riders who can accelerate on Challambra and finish fast
sprinters: Fast finishers who can survive the climb and contest the reduced bunch sprint
allRounders: Versatile riders who can handle the undulating terrain and wind

narratives: Opening Women's WorldTour one-day race of the season attracts top global field
Unpredictable race history - no rider has ever won back-to-back editions
Australian home riders have strong record - domestic talent always competitive
Equal prize money and prestige with the men's race demonstrates parity commitment
Final test of the Australian January racing block before teams head to Europe
raceDetails.historicalContext: Named after Australian cycling legend Cadel Evans, the race was first held in 2015 and elevated to Women's WorldTour status in 2020. The race has earned a reputation for unpredictability, often producing surprise winners and close finishes. Australian riders have historically performed well on home soil.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The Challambra Crescent climb 9km from the finish is where the race explodes. Watch for attacks on the steeper gradients - the climb isn't long but it's punchy enough to shed pure sprinters. Coastal winds throughout can cause echelons and surprise splits. The fast descent and run-in to the Geelong waterfront favors riders who can recover quickly from the climb effort.

primary.notes: Free-to-air broadcast on Channel 7 in Australia

broadcast.notes: First Women's WorldTour one-day race of the season. Full TV production with helicopter coverage.

races.name: Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race
races.description: WorldTour one-day race featuring 182km through Victoria's Surf Coast with the punchy Challambra Crescent climb on a 21km finishing circuit

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Cadel Evans Great Ocean Road Race is the second WorldTour event of the season and first major one-day race. Starting and finishing at Geelong waterfront, the 182km route includes over 2,000m of elevation gain through stunning Surf Coast scenery. After coastal roads past Bells Beach and inland farmland hills, the race enters a 21km finishing circuit completed 3.5 times, featuring four ascents of the decisive Challambra Crescent.

keyClimbs.name: Challambra Crescent
keyClimbs.notes: Climbed 4 times on finishing circuit - final ascent 9km from finish

raceDetails.watchNotes: The punchy Challambra climb, topping out 9km from the finish, has a habit of splitting the field before riders head back toward the waterfront for the final dash. Watch for attacks on the steep 11% sections. Race is famously unpredictable - different winning scenarios play out each year.
narratives: WorldTour teams looking for early season form
Sprint or breakaway? The Challambra climb decides
Local Australian riders motivated on home roads

broadcast.notes: WorldTour one-day race. Highlights typically posted same day on YouTube.

races.name: Volta Comunitat Valenciana
races.description: Five-stage ProSeries race through Spain's Valencian Community featuring team time trial, mountain stages and sprint finales

stages.name: Stage 1: Team Time Trial
stages.description: Opening team time trial to set the GC hierarchy

stageDetails.courseSummary: Opening team time trial to set the GC hierarchy
stageDetails.watchNotes: Team effort - consistency is key. Watch for teams pacing for their GC leader vs going all-out. Gaps can be substantial between top and bottom teams.

stages.name: Stage 2: Mountain Stage
stages.description: First mountain stage with summit finish - key GC day

stageDetails.courseSummary: First mountain stage with summit finish - key GC day
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

stages.name: Stage 3: Mountain Stage
stages.description: Second mountain test through challenging terrain

stageDetails.courseSummary: Second mountain test through challenging terrain
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

stages.name: Stage 4: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Undulating stage that could favor puncheurs or breakaways

stageDetails.courseSummary: Undulating stage that could favor puncheurs or breakaways
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 5: Valencia Sprint
stages.description: Flat finale into Valencia for the sprinters

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat finale into Valencia for the sprinters
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Volta a la Comunitat Valenciana is a key early-season stage race, often used as preparation for spring classics or Grand Tours. The five-stage race typically includes a team time trial opener, challenging mountain stages, and a sprint finale in Valencia.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Strong GC fields use this race to test early form. The TTT opener can create significant time gaps. Mountain stages are decisive for classification.
narratives: Early season form test for GC contenders
Strong Spanish teams on home roads
Sprint teams looking for stage wins

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: UAE Tour Women
races.description: 4-stage Women's WorldTour race in the UAE featuring desert sprints and the decisive Jebel Hafeet summit finish

raceDetails.courseSummary: The UAE Tour Women is the only Women's WorldTour race in the Middle East, featuring four stages across the United Arab Emirates. The race typically includes three flat sprint stages with potential for echelon action in desert crosswinds, and one decisive summit finish to Jebel Hafeet. The mountain finish, averaging 8-9% gradient over the final 10km, has defined the overall classification in every edition.

keyClimbs.name: Jebel Hafeet
keyClimbs.notes: The decisive climb - one of the longest and hardest summit finishes in women's cycling. GC is typically won or lost here.

gcContenders: Strong climbers who can time trial and survive sprint stages
stageHunters: Breakaway specialists looking for stage glory
sprinters: Fast finishers for the three flat stages
climbers: Pure climbers targeting Jebel Hafeet stage victory

narratives: UAE home team ADQ brings strong roster for prestigious home race
Jebel Hafeet summit finish typically decisive for GC - expect aggressive climbing
Desert winds create unpredictable echelon situations on flat stages
Early-season form indicator before European classics campaign
Top-tier WorldTour teams compete with equal vehicles and accommodation
raceDetails.historicalContext: The UAE Tour Women launched in 2023 as the first Women's WorldTour race in the Middle East. Organized by RCS Sport for the Abu Dhabi Sports Council, the race has quickly established itself as a significant early-season test. The Jebel Hafeet climb has become iconic, with the summit finish deciding the overall classification in every edition.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Stages 1, 2, and 4 typically finish in bunch sprints, but desert crosswinds can create echelons and time gaps. Stage 3 to Jebel Hafeet is the queen stage where the GC is decided. Watch for attacks on the steeper sections of the 10km climb. Recovery and positioning through the flat stages is crucial for GC contenders.
raceDetails.gcDynamics: Flat stages → maintain position and bonus seconds → Stage 3 Jebel Hafeet decisive → Final stage survival

stages.name: Stage 1: Dubai Police Officer's Club → Dubai Harbour
stages.description: Opening flat stage through Dubai with sprint finish at Dubai Harbour

stageDetails.courseSummary: Pan-flat opening stage from Dubai Police Officer's Club to Dubai Harbour. Desert roads offer potential for crosswind action. Sprint finish expected.
stageDetails.watchNotes: Watch for sprint teams organizing lead-out trains. Desert crosswinds can split the peloton unexpectedly.

stages.name: Stage 2: Al Dhafra Fort → Al Mirfa
stages.description: Desert stage through Western UAE with coastal finish in Al Mirfa

stageDetails.courseSummary: Desert duel starting from Al Dhafra Fort, heading through desert terrain to the coastal city of Al Mirfa. Exposed roads create high echelon potential.
stageDetails.watchNotes: The most exposed stage for crosswind echelons. GC teams must stay alert. Breakaway opportunities if peloton is nervous.

stages.name: Stage 3: Al Ain → Jebel Hafeet
stages.description: Queen stage with summit finish atop Jebel Hafeet - the decisive GC day

stageDetails.courseSummary: The queen stage starting in Al Ain, traversing desert terrain on Truck Road E30, before the final 10km climb to Jebel Hafeet summit. This is where the GC is decided.

keyClimbs.name: Jebel Hafeet
keyClimbs.notes: The decisive climb - averaging 8-9% for 10km. Young talents often emerge here.

stageDetails.watchNotes: The GC is won or lost on Jebel Hafeet. Watch for early attacks to test rivals. The final 3km are the steepest. This climb has produced breakout performances from young climbers.

stages.name: Stage 4: Abu Dhabi → Abu Dhabi Breakwater
stages.description: Final stage around Abu Dhabi islands with sprint finish at Breakwater

stageDetails.courseSummary: The finale winds through Abu Dhabi, passing through Khalifa City and Yas Marina before island-hopping across Saadiyat, Al Maryah, Al Reem and Yifenah islands. Wide final 5km set up a sprint finish.
stageDetails.watchNotes: Typically a celebration stage for GC leader unless gaps are small. Sprint teams will contest the final stage win. Abu Dhabi waterfront provides spectacular backdrop.

broadcast.notes: Only Women's WorldTour race in the Middle East. Premium production quality with helicopter coverage.

races.name: Muscat Classic
races.description: Punchy one-day classic in Oman preceding the Tour of Oman - favors puncheurs on jagged finish circuit

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Muscat Classic is a standalone one-day race held the day before the Tour of Oman begins. The jagged course in and around Muscat favors puncheurs who can handle the short, sharp climbs in the finale. The race has quickly established itself as a quality early-season event.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Watch for puncheurs who can handle repeated accelerations. The technical finale suits aggressive racing.

races.name: Tour of Oman
races.description: Five-stage ProSeries race through Oman featuring coastal flat stages, desert winds, and the decisive Jebel al Akhdhar (Green Mountain) summit finish

stages.name: Stage 1: Flat Stage
stages.description: Opening flat stage through the desert - likely sprint finish

stageDetails.courseSummary: Opening flat stage through the desert - likely sprint finish
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 2: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Undulating stage with punchy hills - could favor breakaway or puncheurs

stageDetails.courseSummary: Undulating stage with punchy hills - could favor breakaway or puncheurs
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 3: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Another hilly day through the Omani interior

stageDetails.courseSummary: Another hilly day through the Omani interior
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 4: Flat Stage
stages.description: Flat stage likely for the sprinters

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat stage likely for the sprinters
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 5: Jebel al Akhdhar (Green Mountain)
stages.description: Queen stage with summit finish atop the iconic Green Mountain - decisive for GC

stageDetails.courseSummary: Queen stage with summit finish atop the iconic Green Mountain - decisive for GC
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Tour of Oman is a five-stage race showcasing the varied terrain of the Sultanate - from coastal flat roads to desert landscapes and the dramatic Green Mountain. The race typically features sprint stages, hilly tests, and culminates with a decisive summit finish atop Jebel al Akhdhar.

keyClimbs.name: Jebel al Akhdhar (Green Mountain)
keyClimbs.notes: Decisive summit finish - over 2000m altitude

raceDetails.watchNotes: The Green Mountain on the final stage typically decides the overall. Exposed desert roads can see crosswinds split the race on flat stages. Heat is always a factor.
narratives: GC battle decided on Green Mountain
Sprinters have multiple opportunities in opening stages
Desert winds can create chaos on exposed roads

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: Vuelta CV Feminas
races.description: One-day women's race in Spain's Valencian Community - fast sprinter-friendly circuit

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Vuelta CV Feminas is a one-day women's race held in Spain's Valencian Community, typically featuring rolling terrain that favors sprinters.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Fast-paced women's one-day race that usually comes down to a sprint finish.

races.name: Setmana Volta Femenina Comunitat Valenciana
races.description: 4-stage ProSeries race through Spain's Valencia region featuring sprint stages and key summit finishes

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Setmana Ciclista Volta Femenina de la Comunitat Valenciana is a four-stage race through Spain's eastern Valencia region. The race typically features a mix of sprint stages and hilly terrain with categorized climbs that can shake up the general classification. Key summit finishes like the Alto de Barx have decided past editions, making this an important early-season test for all-rounders.

keyClimbs.name: Alto de Barx
keyClimbs.notes: Often the race-deciding climb with summit near finish

keyClimbs.name: Alto de Serra Grossa
keyClimbs.notes: Early selection point on hilly stages

keyClimbs.name: Alto de Barxeta
keyClimbs.notes: Punchy mid-race climb

gcContenders: Versatile riders who can climb and time trial
stageHunters: Attackers looking for breakaway stage wins
sprinters: Fast finishers for the flatter stages

narratives: Key early-season tune-up race before European classics campaign
Spanish regional teams challenge WorldTour squads on home roads
Mediterranean climate offers respite from northern European cold
Intermediate bonus seconds can be decisive in close GC battles
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Setmana Ciclista Volta Valenciana is one of Spain's most important women's stage races, providing an early-season racing opportunity in the warm Mediterranean climate. The race attracts a mix of WorldTour teams and Spanish continental squads, creating entertaining racing dynamics.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The hilly stages with summit finishes like Alto de Barx typically decide the overall classification. Sprint stages can see echelon action in crosswinds along the coast. Watch for attacks on the categorized climbs - gaps established here can be decisive.
raceDetails.gcDynamics: Sprint stages for positioning → Hilly stages for GC selection → Final stage survival

stages.name: Stage 1
stages.description: Opening hilly stage with multiple categorized climbs

stageDetails.courseSummary: Hilly opening stage through the Valencia region featuring several categorized climbs that will test riders' early-season form.
stageDetails.watchNotes: First GC test of the race. Teams will establish positioning for stages to come.

stages.name: Stage 2
stages.description: Rolling stage with sprint finish potential

stageDetails.courseSummary: Undulating stage that may come down to a reduced sprint depending on how the climbs split the peloton.
stageDetails.watchNotes: Intermediate sprints offer bonus seconds. Sprint teams will contest the stage if peloton stays together.

stages.name: Stage 3
stages.description: Queen stage with summit finish - typically GC decisive

stageDetails.courseSummary: The queen stage featuring a summit finish that typically decides the overall classification.

keyClimbs.name: Alto de Barx
keyClimbs.notes: Often the decisive climb for GC

stageDetails.watchNotes: The GC will likely be decided here. Watch for attacks on the steeper sections. Teams with climbing leaders will control the pace.

stages.name: Stage 4
stages.description: Final stage - likely sprint finish

stageDetails.courseSummary: Final stage that typically ends in a bunch sprint unless GC gaps are tight.
stageDetails.watchNotes: Celebration stage for the leader unless small time gaps. Sprint teams will contest the final win.

broadcast.notes: Spanish ProSeries stage race. Coverage may vary by stage.

races.name: Figueira Champions Classic
races.description: Portuguese one-day classic featuring 197km of rolling coastal terrain with decisive Rua Parque Florestal climb on finish circuit

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Figueira Champions Classic is a 197km one-day race along Portugal's central coast, finishing in Figueira da Foz. The decisive section is a finishing circuit featuring three ascents of Rua Parque Florestal (2.3km at 7.1%), where attacks on the final lap can prove decisive.

keyClimbs.name: Rua Parque Florestal
keyClimbs.notes: Climbed 3 times on finishing circuit - final ascent ~10km from finish

raceDetails.watchNotes: The race is typically aggressive on the final circuit. Strong puncheurs can attack on the Rua Parque Florestal and hold off the chasers. Recent winner António Morgado attacked with 21km to go and soloed to victory.
narratives: Portugal's only professional classic - home riders highly motivated
Puncheurs vs sprinters on the finishing circuit
Early season form indicator for WorldTour riders

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: Clasica de Almeria
races.description: Spanish one-day classic featuring 189km through Andalusia with several category 3 climbs - typically ends in a sprint

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Clásica de Almería is a 189km one-day race in Spain's southern Andalusia region. The course includes several category 3 and 4 climbs (Alto de Celin, Alto de La Alqueria, Alto de Fuente Marbella) but these are positioned far enough from the finish that the race typically concludes in a bunch sprint in Roquetas de Mar.
raceDetails.watchNotes: A classic early-season sprinter's race in warm Andalusian sunshine. While the climbs can be used to fatigue the peloton, well-organized sprint teams typically control the finale. Recent winners include fast men like Fretin, Kooij, and Ewan.
narratives: Sprinters' early season tune-up
Warm weather attracts WorldTour teams
Spanish teams fighting for home glory

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: UAE Tour
races.description: Seven-stage WorldTour race in the UAE featuring flat sprint stages, ITT, and decisive summit finishes at Jebel Jais and Jebel Hafeet

stages.name: Stage 1: Sprint Stage
stages.description: Opening sprint stage through the desert - flat with possible uphill kick to finish

stageDetails.courseSummary: Opening sprint stage through the desert - flat with possible uphill kick to finish
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 2: Individual Time Trial
stages.description: Fast flat time trial for the TT specialists

stageDetails.courseSummary: Fast flat time trial for the TT specialists
stageDetails.watchNotes: Pure time trial - every second counts. Watch for aero positions and pacing strategy. TT specialists can gain significant time on pure climbers.

stages.name: Stage 3: Jebel Jais
stages.description: First mountain stage with summit finish atop Jebel Jais - 20km climb at 5% average

stageDetails.courseSummary: First mountain stage with summit finish atop Jebel Jais - 20km climb at 5% average
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

keyClimbs.name: Jebel Jais
keyClimbs.notes: Summit finish - decisive for GC

stages.name: Stage 4: Sprint Stage
stages.description: Flat stage through the desert - beware of crosswinds

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat stage through the desert - beware of crosswinds
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 5: Sprint Stage
stages.description: Another flat day in Dubai - sprint opportunity

stageDetails.courseSummary: Another flat day in Dubai - sprint opportunity
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 6: Sprint Stage
stages.description: Flat stage to Abu Dhabi - final sprint opportunity before finale

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat stage to Abu Dhabi - final sprint opportunity before finale
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 7: Jebel Hafeet
stages.description: Queen stage and finale with summit finish atop Jebel Hafeet - decisive for GC

stageDetails.courseSummary: Queen stage and finale with summit finish atop Jebel Hafeet - decisive for GC
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The UAE Tour is the only WorldTour race in the Middle East, featuring seven stages across the United Arab Emirates. The format balances sprint opportunities on flat desert roads with two crucial mountain stages - Jebel Jais mid-race and the iconic Jebel Hafeet summit finish on the finale.

keyClimbs.name: Jebel Jais
keyClimbs.notes: UAE's highest peak - stage 3 summit finish

keyClimbs.name: Jebel Hafeet
keyClimbs.notes: Final stage summit - decisive for overall

raceDetails.watchNotes: The exposed desert roads can produce dangerous crosswinds that split the race on flat stages. Jebel Hafeet on the finale typically decides the GC - 10km at 8.5% average with kicks up to 11%. Top GC contenders often target this race for early season form.
narratives: GC battle between climbing and TT abilities
Four sprint opportunities for fast finishers
Desert crosswinds can reshape the race at any moment
Jebel Hafeet always delivers drama on the final day

sprinters: Multiple sprint opportunities attract top fast men

broadcast.notes: WorldTour stage race. Live coverage and stage highlights available.

races.name: Volta ao Algarve
races.description: Five-stage ProSeries race in Portugal's Algarve featuring Alto da Fóia mountain stage and decisive Alto do Malhão summit time trial finale

stages.name: Stage 1: Flat Stage
stages.description: Opening stage - typically flat for the sprinters

stageDetails.courseSummary: Opening stage - typically flat for the sprinters
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 2: Alto da Fóia
stages.description: Mountain stage to Alto da Fóia - first GC test at Algarve's highest point

stageDetails.courseSummary: Mountain stage to Alto da Fóia - first GC test at Algarve's highest point
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

stages.name: Stage 3: Flat Stage
stages.description: Flat stage through the Algarve - sprint opportunity

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat stage through the Algarve - sprint opportunity
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 4: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Undulating stage - could favor breakaway or reduced bunch sprint

stageDetails.courseSummary: Undulating stage - could favor breakaway or reduced bunch sprint
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 5: Alto do Malhão ITT
stages.description: Decisive uphill time trial to Alto do Malhão - final GC decider

stageDetails.courseSummary: Decisive uphill time trial to Alto do Malhão - final GC decider
stageDetails.watchNotes: Pure time trial - every second counts. Watch for aero positions and pacing strategy. TT specialists can gain significant time on pure climbers.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Volta ao Algarve is a prestigious early-season race in southern Portugal, traditionally attracting top GC contenders testing their form. The five-stage format typically includes flat stages for sprinters, the Alto da Fóia mountain test, and the decisive Alto do Malhão summit time trial finale.

keyClimbs.name: Alto da Fóia
keyClimbs.notes: Highest point in the Algarve - stage 2 summit finish

keyClimbs.name: Alto do Malhão
keyClimbs.notes: Final ITT summit - typically decides overall

raceDetails.watchNotes: Recent winners include Vingegaard, Evenepoel, and Pogačar - this race attracts top talent. The Alto do Malhão ITT on the final day is unique and decisive. Weather in the Algarve is typically pleasant, making this a popular early-season race.
narratives: Top GC contenders testing early season form
Alto do Malhão ITT can overturn GC gaps
Portuguese fans passionate about home race

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: Vuelta a Andalucia - Ruta del Sol

stages.description: Opening stage through mountainous Andalusian terrain - first test for GC riders

stageDetails.courseSummary: Opening stage through mountainous Andalusian terrain - first test for GC riders
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 2: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Punchy stage with uphill finish - favors attackers

stageDetails.courseSummary: Punchy stage with uphill finish - favors attackers
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 3: Hilly Stage
stages.description: Rolling terrain - sprint possible if fast men survive

stageDetails.courseSummary: Rolling terrain - sprint possible if fast men survive
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 4: Long Hilly Stage
stages.description: Longest stage of the race - attrition through distance and terrain

stageDetails.courseSummary: Longest stage of the race - attrition through distance and terrain
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stages.name: Stage 5: Mountain Stage
stages.description: Final stage through Andalusian mountains - last chance to reshape GC

stageDetails.courseSummary: Final stage through Andalusian mountains - last chance to reshape GC

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Vuelta a Andalucia (Ruta del Sol) is one of Spain's most historic stage races, held annually in February through the sun-baked roads of Andalusia. The challenging terrain with multiple climbs each day makes this a race for puncheurs and all-rounders rather than pure sprinters.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Expect aggressive racing throughout - there are few easy stages in this race. Spanish teams and riders are particularly motivated. Hot conditions in Andalusia add to the challenge.
narratives: Spanish teams targeting home race glory
Puncheurs and climbers have multiple opportunities
No hiding places - every stage is demanding

broadcast.notes: ProSeries race - check GCN/Eurosport for highlights coverage

races.name: Omloop Nieuwsblad Women
races.description: Opening Weekend classic through the Flemish Ardennes featuring iconic bergs like the Muur van Geraardsbergen and Bosberg

raceDetails.courseSummary: Omloop Het Nieuwsblad Women is the first major cobbled classic of the European season, traditionally marking the start of 'Opening Weekend' alongside the men's race and Kuurne-Brussel-Kuurne. The 130km route from Ghent to Ninove takes riders through the heart of the Flemish Ardennes, tackling the same iconic bergs (hellingen) and cobbled sectors that define the Tour of Flanders. The decisive Muur van Geraardsbergen and Bosberg climbs come inside the final 15km.

keyClimbs.name: Muur van Geraardsbergen (Kapelmuur)
keyClimbs.notes: The iconic 'Chapel Wall' - steep cobbles through woodland to the chapel at the top. Often race-deciding.

keyClimbs.name: Bosberg
keyClimbs.notes: Final climb with 9km to the finish. Long enough for attackers, close enough for chasers.

keyClimbs.name: Molenberg
keyClimbs.notes: Sharp berg that can trigger early selection

keyClimbs.name: Berendries
keyClimbs.notes: Technical berg before the final showdown

keySectors.name: Paddestraat
keySectors.description: First cobbled sector, sets the rhythm

keySectors.name: Haaghoek
keySectors.description: Rough cobbles that can cause splits before the finale

cobbleSpecialists: Riders who thrive on the rough cobbled bergs
puncheurs: Explosive attackers who can power over the Muur
sprinters: Strong sprinters who can survive the hellingen
allRounders: Versatile riders who can attack and sprint

narratives: Opening Weekend marks the start of the 'real' European racing season
First test on the iconic Flemish climbs before Tour of Flanders
Belgian home riders seek glory on familiar roads
Cold, wet February conditions add to the challenge
Form indicator for the entire Spring Classics campaign
raceDetails.historicalContext: Omloop Het Nieuwsblad has traditionally marked the opening of the Spring Classics since 1945. Named after the Flemish newspaper Het Nieuwsblad, the race takes place in the heart of cycling country, on many of the same cobbles and bergs used in the Tour of Flanders. The women's edition has become a major WorldTour event, often producing surprise winners and dramatic racing.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The Muur van Geraardsbergen is where the race explodes - the steep cobbles shed pure sprinters and force attackers to play their cards. The Bosberg 9km from the finish is the last chance to escape. After the Bosberg, a 9km run-in to Ninove often comes down to a reduced group sprint. Cold conditions and tired legs from winter training can produce unexpected results.

primary.notes: Live coverage on TNT Sports (formerly BT Sport)

broadcast.notes: Opening Weekend is a major event in Belgium with extensive local TV coverage. Women's race runs alongside the men's event.

raceDetails.courseSummary: The Faun Drôme Classic is a French one-day race held in the Drôme department of southeastern France. Starting and finishing in Étoile-sur-Rhône, the 200km route traverses the rolling terrain between the Rhône Valley and the Vercors foothills. Despite its 'flat' classification, the parcours features several short climbs that can break up the peloton before the finale.

sprinters: Fast finishers capable of surviving selective climbs
puncheurs: Riders who can attack on late climbs
allRounders: Strong all-rounders using this as spring season opener

narratives: Early-season test for sprinters ahead of spring classics
French teams looking for home soil victories
Form indicator race for Paris-Nice preparation
raceDetails.historicalContext: Formerly known as the Classic Sud Ardèche, the race was rebranded as the Drôme Classic and has grown in stature as a key early-season race in France. It serves as preparation for both sprinters targeting Milan-San Remo and classics specialists.
raceDetails.watchNotes: Watch for breakaways on the final climbs trying to stay away from the bunch sprint. If the race comes together, expect a bunch sprint where positioning through the final kilometers is crucial.

raceDetails.courseSummary: Kuurne-Brussels-Kuurne is a classic Belgian one-day race held on the day after Omloop Het Nieuwsblad as part of the 'Opening Weekend' of Belgian cycling. The 200km race starts and finishes in Kuurne, West Flanders, traversing through Brussels and tackling multiple bergs and cobbled sectors. The race features the famous hellingen (short steep hills) of Flanders and selective cobbled sections that test spring classics fitness.

keySectors.name: Oude Kwaremont
keySectors.description: Classic Flemish cobbled climb - selective but not decisive at this point

keySectors.name: Koppenberg
keySectors.description: Short but brutal 22% gradient cobbles - often causes splits

cobbleSpecialists: Flanders specialists using this as Tour prep
puncheurs: Riders who can handle the hellingen
sprinters: Fast finishers with cobble survival skills

narratives: Second day of Opening Weekend tests tired legs from Omloop
Flandrien classics specialists fine-tuning form before Tour of Flanders
Weather often plays a major role - wind, rain, and cold add to difficulty
Can sprinters survive the cobbles for a bunch sprint?
raceDetails.historicalContext: First held in 1901, Kuurne-Brussels-Kuurne is one of the oldest races in Belgium. The race gained prominence as the companion event to Omloop Het Nieuwsblad, together forming the unofficial 'Opening Weekend' that kicks off the Belgian spring classics season. Many riders use it as final preparation before the Spring Classics block.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The race can go multiple ways: breakaway success on the bergs, late attacks on the final climbs, or a reduced bunch sprint. Watch for the Koppenberg and Oude Kwaremont to create selection. Tired legs from Omloop the day before often leads to surprises.

races.name: Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn's Cup Tour of Thailand
Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn's Cup Women's Tour of Thailand
Région Pays de La Loire Tour
Région Pays de la Loire Tour Féminin
GP Beiras e Serra da Estrela

raceDetails.courseSummary: The 2026 Tour de France starts in Barcelona, Spain for the first time in history, featuring 21 stages over 23 days covering approximately 3,333km. The Grand Départ begins with a team time trial up Montjuïc, followed by three stages in Catalonia before crossing into France. The race features eight mountain stages including summit finishes at iconic climbs, two individual time trials, and rest days in key positions. The third week features a demanding finale through the Alps with classic climbs including Mont Ventoux and the Galibier region.

keyClimbs.name: Mont Ventoux
keyClimbs.notes: The Beast of Provence - legendary summit finish. 21.5km at 7.5% via Bédoin.

keyClimbs.name: Col du Galibier
keyClimbs.notes: Classic Alpine giant, often decisive for GC. 18km at 6.9% to 2642m.

keyClimbs.name: Alpe d'Huez
keyClimbs.notes: Iconic 21 hairpins to Dutch Corner. 13.8km at 8.1%, penultimate stage.

keyClimbs.name: Montjuïc
keyClimbs.notes: TTT opener - short punchy climb through Barcelona park, ridden twice.

stageHunters: Breakaway specialists for medium mountain stages
TT specialists for both time trials
climbers: Pure climbers for high mountain stages

narratives: Barcelona Grand Départ brings Spanish crowds and a historic first for Catalunya
Third week Alps gauntlet: Mont Ventoux, Galibier, and Alpe d'Huez in final 5 stages
Two time trials (TTT + ITT) create significant time gaps for TT specialists
Can the yellow jersey survive three consecutive mountain stages before Paris?
New generation of GC riders challenging established order
raceDetails.historicalContext: The Tour de France is cycling's most prestigious race, first held in 1903. This will be the first Grand Départ from Barcelona. Previous Spanish starts have come from Bilbao (2023) and San Sebastian. The race has shaped legends from Coppi and Merckx to Indurain and modern champions. The yellow jersey (maillot jaune) has been the symbol of race leadership since 1919.
raceDetails.watchNotes: The TTT opener will set early time gaps between teams. First mountain summit finish creates initial GC selection. Watch for the first rest day as recovery point before the second major mountain block. The final week's consecutive mountain stages (Ventoux, Alps) typically decide the race. Paris finale is traditionally processional until the Champs-Élysées sprints.
raceDetails.gcDynamics: TTT creates early team gaps → First mountains establish GC hierarchy → Second week mountain stages refine gaps → Final week Alps make-or-break for contenders → ITT as final GC test before Paris

stages.name: Stage 1: Barcelona → Barcelona

stageDetails.courseSummary: Team time trial with two climbs of Montjuïc; technical city-center course

stages.description: Flat sprinters' stage in the Dordogne

stageDetails.courseSummary: Flat sprinters' stage in the Dordogne
stageDetails.watchNotes: Sprint teams will control the pace. Watch for crosswinds that can split the peloton on exposed roads. Late attacks possible if finale includes any punchy sections.

stages.name: Stage 9: Malemort → Ussel
stages.description: Hilly breakaway terrain in the Corrèze

stageDetails.courseSummary: Hilly breakaway terrain in the Corrèze
stageDetails.watchNotes: Punchy terrain will test the sprinters. Breakaways have a chance if they build enough gap over the climbs. GC teams may use the hills to put pressure on rivals.

stageDetails.courseSummary: First rest day in the Cantal region

stages.name: Stage 10: Aurillac → Le Lioran
stages.description: Bastille Day mountain stage in the Massif Central with summit finish at Le Lioran

stageDetails.courseSummary: Bastille Day mountain stage in the Massif Central with summit finish at Le Lioran
stageDetails.watchNotes: Key GC day. Expect attacks on the final climb. Teams will set tempo to drop sprinters before the decisive section. Watch for long-range moves if multiple major climbs.

stageDetails.watchNotes: Pure time trial - every second counts. Watch for aero positions and pacing strategy. TT specialists can gain significant time on pure climbers.
